test_metadata.test_title: Poverty, Employment and Recent Development - Practice MCQ Test
test_metadata.subject: Indian Economy
test_metadata.sub_topic: Poverty, Unemployment, Human Development, Inclusive Growth
test_metadata.description: Conceptual and application-based MCQs on poverty, employment, inequality, human development and inclusive growth in the Indian context.

questions.question_text: Poverty line in most official approaches is primarily defined in terms of:

options.option_text: Level of education attained
Minimum income or consumption required to meet basic needs
Ownership of luxury goods
Access to internet connectivity

questions.question_text: Head Count Ratio (HCR) as a poverty measure refers to:

options.option_text: Number of poor per 1,000 population
Percentage of population below the poverty line
Average income of the poor
Gap between richest and poorest decile

questions.question_text: Which one of the following is a limitation of Head Count Ratio as a poverty measure?

options.option_text: It cannot be calculated from survey data
It ignores how far below the poverty line the poor are
It includes the non-poor in calculation
It cannot be compared over time

questions.question_text: The concept of 'absolute poverty' primarily focuses on:

options.option_text: Inequality between rich and poor
Inability to meet minimum basic consumption needs
Relative position of income in society
Ownership of land only

questions.question_text: Relative poverty is best illustrated by which of the following situations?

options.option_text: Household cannot buy enough food for one meal
Household income is below a fixed minimum consumption requirement
Household income is significantly lower than median income of society
Household owns no land at all

questions.question_text: Multidimensional Poverty Index (MPI) typically includes indicators related to:

options.option_text: Only income and consumption
Health, education and living standards
Only wealth and assets
Only unemployment rate

questions.question_text: In India, large sections of the poor are typically concentrated among which groups?

options.option_text: Urban salaried middle class
Large industrialists
Landless agricultural labourers and casual workers
Top income decile only

questions.question_text: The term 'vicious circle of poverty' refers to a situation where:

options.option_text: High income leads to high savings and growth
Low income leads to low saving, low investment and hence low income again
High taxation leads to poverty directly
Only external debt causes poverty

questions.question_text: In the context of employment statistics, 'labour force' includes:

options.option_text: All persons in the working-age group
Only those who are employed
Those who are either employed or actively seeking work
Only those who are unemployed

questions.question_text: Which of the following best defines 'open unemployment'?

options.option_text: People working below their skill level
People who are willing and able to work but cannot find work at prevailing wage rates
People not willing to work
People working part-time by choice

questions.question_text: Disguised unemployment is generally associated with which of the following situations in Indian context?

options.option_text: Highly mechanised factories
Service sector offices
Overcrowded agriculture where marginal productivity of some workers is near zero
High-tech IT companies

questions.question_text: Which one of the following is NOT a type of unemployment discussed in development economics?

options.option_text: Cyclical unemployment
Frictional unemployment
Structural unemployment
Absolute unemployment of machines only

questions.question_text: The informal (unorganised) sector in India is typically characterised by:

options.option_text: Written contracts and social security benefits
High regulation and strong unionisation
Absence of formal contracts, low wages and lack of social security
Exclusively public sector jobs

questions.question_text: Which of the following bodies conducts employment and unemployment surveys like the Periodic Labour Force Survey in India?

options.option_text: Reserve Bank of India
National Statistical Office (NSO)
NITI Aayog
Finance Commission

questions.question_text: Which of the following indicators measures the proportion of working-age population that is either employed or actively seeking work?

options.option_text: Unemployment rate
Labour Force Participation Rate (LFPR)
Work Participation Rate
Dependency ratio

questions.question_text: Underemployment is best described by which of the following cases?

options.option_text: A person working full-time at high wages
A person working part-time involuntarily when full-time work is desired
A retired person not looking for work
A student studying full-time

questions.question_text: Which of the following policy measures can directly help in reducing structural unemployment over the long run?

options.option_text: Across-the-board wage cut in all sectors
Skill development, education and sectoral diversification
Closing all training institutions
Only raising interest rates frequently

questions.question_text: Demographic dividend refers to a situation where an economy has:

options.option_text: High proportion of elderly population
High proportion of working-age population relative to dependents
Very low birth rate only
Only high migration inflows

questions.question_text: Which of the following best captures the idea of 'inclusive growth' in Indian planning discourse?

options.option_text: High GDP growth regardless of distribution
Growth that is broad-based across sectors and includes vulnerable groups in its benefits
Growth confined only to urban regions
Growth driven only by stock market performance

questions.question_text: Human Development Index (HDI) is a composite measure of which of the following dimensions?

options.option_text: Income, environment and technology
Health, education and standard of living
Agriculture, industry and services
Population growth, literacy and inflation

questions.question_text: Which of the following is a valid criticism of GDP as a measure of development?

options.option_text: It ignores market transactions entirely
It does not capture distribution of income and quality of life directly
It is calculated only every 10 years
It includes unpaid household work fully

questions.question_text: Gini coefficient is used as a measure of:

options.option_text: Poverty depth
Income or wealth inequality
Employment rate
Human development level

questions.question_text: Which of the following public programmes is primarily aimed at providing legal guarantee of wage employment in rural areas of India?

options.option_text: PMGSY
MGNREGA
PM-KISAN
PMJDY

questions.question_text: Which of the following schemes is directly related to financial inclusion in India?

options.option_text: PMJDY
PMFBY
PMGSY
PMAY-G

questions.question_text: Public Distribution System (PDS) in India primarily aims at:

options.option_text: Subsidised supply of food grains to vulnerable sections
Supply of luxury goods to rich households
Export promotion of food grains
Subsidised credit to industries

questions.question_text: Leakages in social welfare schemes often refer to which of the following problems?

options.option_text: Excessive coverage of all poor households
Benefits not reaching intended beneficiaries due to corruption, diversion or inefficiency
Over-reporting of poverty only
Reduction in administrative costs

questions.question_text: Direct Benefit Transfer (DBT) in India primarily aims to:

options.option_text: Provide benefits in-kind only through PDS shops
Transfer subsidies and benefits directly into bank accounts of beneficiaries
Eliminate all subsidies
Provide only employment in rural areas

questions.question_text: Which of the following is a likely effect of high and persistent unemployment in an economy?

options.option_text: Higher tax revenue automatically
Higher poverty and social tensions
Guaranteed higher GDP growth
Lower dependency ratio

questions.question_text: Which of the following indicates 'working poor' in labour economics?

options.option_text: Persons not in labour force but rich
Persons who are employed but still live below the poverty line
Persons who are unemployed but wealthy
Persons working in government sector only

questions.question_text: Which of the following policy interventions is MOST likely to reduce poverty in the long run in a sustainable way?

options.option_text: Only temporary loan waivers without productivity gains
Improved education, health, skills and productive employment opportunities
Unlimited consumption subsidies with no targeting
Perpetual dependence on informal moneylenders

questions.question_text: The concept of 'social protection' in development economics refers to:

options.option_text: Policies that only protect industries from imports
Policies and programmes to reduce vulnerability, poverty and risk (like pensions, insurance, safety nets)
Only protection of environment
Only legal protection of property rights

questions.question_text: Which of the following best explains 'capability approach' to development put forward by Amartya Sen?

options.option_text: Focusing only on GDP as indicator of welfare
Emphasising income alone as measure of capability
Viewing development as enhancement of people’s capabilities and freedoms to lead lives they value
Considering only physical infrastructure as development

questions.question_text: Urban poverty in India is often characterised by which of the following features?

options.option_text: Sprawling slums with poor housing, sanitation and informal employment
High agricultural productivity
Complete absence of informal sector
Universal access to social security and housing

questions.question_text: Which of the following is a plausible consequence of high regional disparities in development within a country?

options.option_text: Perfectly uniform migration
Increased internal migration, social tensions and unequal opportunities
Guaranteed political stability everywhere
Only higher tax revenues for poorer regions

questions.question_text: Which of the following is an example of a 'self-employment' programme aimed at poverty alleviation and livelihood promotion in rural areas?

options.option_text: Schemes for high-end stock trading
Programmes that organise rural poor into SHGs and promote micro-enterprises
Only cash transfer to rich households
Only free higher education for elites

questions.question_text: Skill development initiatives are MOST directly linked with which of the following development goals?

options.option_text: Increasing only capital gains tax
Enhancing employability, productivity and wages of workers
Reducing human capital
Decreasing labour force participation

questions.question_text: Which statement best reflects the relationship between economic growth and poverty reduction in development experience?

options.option_text: Growth automatically reduces poverty irrespective of distribution
Growth has no relation with poverty at all
Growth combined with targeted social policies is more effective in reducing poverty
Only redistribution without growth is sufficient forever

questions.question_text: Persistent 'jobless growth' in an economy refers to a situation where:

options.option_text: GDP grows with commensurate growth in employment
GDP grows but employment growth remains stagnant or very low
Employment grows but GDP falls
Neither GDP nor employment grows

questions.question_text: Which of the following can be considered an indicator of 'quality of employment' rather than mere quantity?

options.option_text: Number of hours worked only
Presence of social security, decent wages and safe working conditions
Only sectoral distribution of employment
Only number of formal sector jobs

questions.question_text: Gender gap in labour force participation in India implies that:

options.option_text: Men and women participate equally everywhere
Women’s participation in labour market is significantly lower than men’s
Women’s participation is always higher than men’s
Gender has no relation with labour statistics

questions.question_text: Which of the following policies would MOST LIKELY support both employment generation and environmental sustainability?

options.option_text: Promoting only resource-intensive industries ignoring pollution
Large-scale afforestation, renewable energy and eco-tourism projects
Banning all industrial activities
Subsidising fossil fuels indefinitely

questions.question_text: Which among the following is a typical feature of rural–urban migration in developing economies like India?

options.option_text: Movement of population from urban to rural areas for agriculture
Migration from rural areas to urban centres in search of better employment opportunities
Zero migration between regions
Movement only of elderly population to cities

questions.question_text: Which of the following reflects under-nutrition as a dimension of poverty and development?

options.option_text: High consumption of luxury foods
Calorie and protein intake below minimum recommended levels
Exclusive dependence on imported food
Only high body mass index (BMI)

questions.question_text: Which of the following development approaches is most consistent with Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs)?

options.option_text: Exclusive focus on economic growth with no concern for environment or equity
Balancing economic growth with social inclusion and environmental protection
Ignoring social indicators entirely
Stopping all industrial development

questions.question_text: Which of the following best exemplifies inter-generational transmission of poverty?

options.option_text: Each generation independently determining its income
Children of poor households facing limited access to health, education and thus remaining poor as adults
Sudden wealth gains due to lottery
High social mobility in education and jobs

questions.question_text: Which of the following is a direct indicator of human capital formation relevant for development analysis?

options.option_text: Number of luxury cars sold
Expenditure on education and health
Amount of gold imported
Volume of speculative stock trade

questions.question_text: Which factor can exacerbate both poverty and vulnerability among informal workers during economic shocks?

options.option_text: Comprehensive social insurance coverage
Lack of job security, savings and social protection
Long-term employment contracts with benefits
Stable and diversified sources of income

questions.question_text: Which of the following can be considered a 'pull factor' for rural–urban migration in India?

options.option_text: Crop failure and drought in rural areas
Better job opportunities, education and services in urban areas
Landlessness and agrarian distress in villages
Natural disasters in rural regions

questions.question_text: Which of the following combinations would BEST support 'pro-poor growth' in an economy?

options.option_text: High growth with rising inequality and stagnant employment
Moderate to high growth, rising productive employment and targeted social programmes
Low growth with no redistribution
Only high redistribution without any growth or employment creation

questions.question_text: In the context of Indian economy, 'recent development' perspective in poverty and employment would MOST appropriately focus on:

options.option_text: Only historical data without current trends
Interactions between growth, structural change, technology, informality and social protection
Only agriculture and no other sector
Ignoring employment quality and focusing only on GDP numbers
